results.content_html:
Perfect introduction into socket.io. Nice tutorial projects with increasing complexity but easy to follow along. In addition to the very detailed explanation of socket.io you also get a little introduction into canvas rendering, node and react - a nice addon.

// irony on
What triggers the hell out of me is the fact that the presenter writes code comments first and then comments them out when he's done instead of starting with the double slash. DISGUSTING!
// irony off

results.content: Exciting and entertaining! A good course even for experienced developers. The course has useful details.
results.content_html: Exciting and entertaining! A good course even for experienced developers. The course has useful details.

results.content:
I don't' consider my self as intermediate level programmer, however Robert explain each topic so well, that looks like kid's play, because of that and his modular way to structure the course, I was able to implement the knowlege in my Vue projects.
I have taken other courses, but none like this, Rob goes deep with the topics, I got surprised with the multithreading part.
Rob is a very active sensei updating the course and answering questions. I can't wait to get dirty with the upcoming streaming videos section.
Finally, socket.io is very useful and will boost your programing skills and will head you over others.

results.content:
Well I'm just at the 10th lesson where we start with the basic of socket.io and I already love your manner to teach. The rhythm step to step is just excellent! Thank you!

___UPDATE half of the course___
Still excellent, among dozens of courses done on udemy that's my favourite because contrary to most of the course you come back to your code and explain well why you did that in that way, what each line does and you speak with joy and fun even if it's not the topic that would make laugh a lot of people. ;-)

results.content:
The first 3 sections of this course are all you need. The rest is a long and scatty presentation of, admittedly, some great stuff, IF you have the time to reverse engineer the concepts for your own use case. I have no doubt that the presenter has amassed a good deal of knowledge on the topic, but the (re)presentation could do with consolidating into logical parts rather than flit around documentation trying to cross of areas covered.
The repo could also do with some tidying as it presently consists of a snapshot of what I would expect the WIP version to look like, rather than a 'release'.
Overall, I DID learn about the basic topic through this course, which will certainly make further research easier.
results.content_html:
The first 3 sections of this course are all you need. The rest is a long and scatty presentation of, admittedly, some great stuff, IF you have the time to reverse engineer the concepts for your own use case. I have no doubt that the presenter has amassed a good deal of knowledge on the topic, but the (re)presentation could do with consolidating into logical parts rather than flit around documentation trying to cross of areas covered.
The repo could also do with some tidying as it presently consists of a snapshot of what I would expect the WIP version to look like, rather than a 'release'.
Overall, I DID learn about the basic topic through this course, which will certainly make further research easier.

results.content: Rob is a very good teacher. He does everything step by step, explains everything well, and often repeats himself (when needed). At the same time, you feel very well treated by him, keep in mind this is not a beginners course, and that is great about it. There is some understanding that, the basics should be already known (also explained in the course description), so if you are somewhat experienced developer and want to learn more I definitely recommend Rob as a teacher. I'm also certain that I will be joining his courses later in the future.

results.content: I have to say... this is likely to become one of the best, if not _the_ best, courses I've ever took on Udemy. Instructor's talent of identifying what _must_ be talked about in order to get the full message across is amazing. I rejoiced when I've heard him saying early on that this is not a "quickstart" type of a course; and he proved this to be the case. I'm not even at the half of the course yet, but he totally won me over. And I've been waiting for a course to explain the websockets - this does that, and goes far beyond. 7/5.

results.content: Alright, first two sections are not really necessary, they give extra information around the protocols etc that socket io is built on. There is also some just reading of MDN and Socket IO documentation. Finally there is virtually no explanation when it comes to the IDE and code files setup.

response.content:
What help would you like to see surrounding the IDE, Stephen?

I’ve had a lot of requests to spend time going through the docs, so that’s in there by demand, though I understand if you are already accomplished at reading docs.

I’ve found covering underlying technologies essential to learning a new concept. Again, I understand if you are already familiar with them, but I’ve had a lot of success teaching that way. Let me know any specific requests and good luck!
response.content_html:
What help would you like to see surrounding the IDE, Stephen?

I’ve had a lot of requests to spend time going through the docs, so that’s in there by demand, though I understand if you are already accomplished at reading docs.

I’ve found covering underlying technologies essential to learning a new concept. Again, I understand if you are already familiar with them, but I’ve had a lot of success teaching that way. Let me know any specific requests and good luck!

results.content: Well, the course is great for novices. What is bad to me is a code style (including file names), and the level of abstractions made. That code far from ready for production, and I'm not speaking for deployment or DevOps things, but its about a mess that tooks place in the code. Btw as I've mentioned -- great for novices and for those who just needs to understand the basic mechanics of how socket.io works. Really good job, thanks.

results.content:
Course is generally great, with high quality content and good projects to practice. But the explnation is pretty bad, basically like someone reading PPT in a meeting and switching back and forth between the codes and docs, just annoying and distracting. 

Another problem is the demo codes look pretty messy, naming is one issue, the bigger issue is tutor constantly wrote bugs and quickly fix, maybe missing a parameter, maybe forget to import some library, so if you miss any of his correction, then it won't work. 

Coding setions and explnataion should be separated strictly.

Don't use tons of comments in editor, green or gray font are not clear enough and messing around your codes. Use some professinal tool to demostrate your idea, it takes a bit of more time but a big improvement.
results.content_html:

results.content:
Half way through the course. Socket io seems to be a confusing but the way instructor has explained is amazing. He goes through the entire documentation, covering each and everything. Also during the project he explained with proper reason everything he is doing. 
Though I am halfway throught, already purchase express course from the same instructor. No doubt he is a brilliant teacher. Looking forward to more indepth courses from the same teacher - like advance Nodejs.

Edit: Compete the course. And I it is total worth it. Especially the last project, when he use redis and cluster. Though I didn't understand how cluster work and how redis kick in, initially but after spending some time with the code and with some googling it becomes clear. Thank you Robert for going out of the scope and explaing these concept also.

results.content:
Great course so far! Robert does a fantastic job of explaining the underlying technology behind socket.io and how it works. This is not just a simple "Let's build an app" course, but a thorough overview of the socket.io library. 
I'm going to go find other courses that Rob has put together and sign up for them. Great work!
results.content_html:
Great course so far! Robert does a fantastic job of explaining the underlying technology behind socket.io and how it works. This is not just a simple "Let's build an app" course, but a thorough overview of the socket.io library.
I'm going to go find other courses that Rob has put together and sign up for them. Great work!

results.content: So far it's a great match! I love that the instructor is planning to explain the underlying technologies that go into what we are about to learn. I also like that he explains the tools he is using and why he uses them. I don't quite like the digital whiteboarding. I'm more of a fan of planned out slides... but that is in no way a deal breaker and it seems to work for this instructor's personal flow and process.

results.content:
I enjoyed the course. The multi-user applications demonstrate the 
use of Socket.IO beautifully. Lots of in-depth explanations provide a wealth of  information to guide you through the process of  setting up
your own creations. Finally, the dashboard application was a great foundation for those wanting to organize similar client features.
results.content_html:
I enjoyed the course. The multi-user applications demonstrate the
use of Socket.IO beautifully. Lots of in-depth explanations provide a wealth of information to guide you through the process of setting up
your own creations. Finally, the dashboard application was a great foundation for those wanting to organize similar client features.

results.content: Very fun and quick-paced. This is an advanced course and you're expected to be familiar with ES6+, MongoDB (local) and React, and do your own research. Considering socket.io v2 is the method of choice for building interactive and practical apps with nodejs, this course is a must if you want to make things that impress people as a modern web developer
results.content_html: Very fun and quick-paced. This is an advanced course and you're expected to be familiar with ES6+, MongoDB (local) and React, and do your own research. Considering socket.io v2 is the method of choice for building interactive and practical apps with nodejs, this course is a must if you want to make things that impress people as a modern web developer

results.content:
Pros:
Projects are easy to follow
Project 1 and 2 are easy and I feel I learned a lot about sockets

Cons:
Projects are more a walk through and I find myself doing more copying than coding
Uses React Class Components in project 3 which is a little outdated

Project 3 throws a lot of new technologies (redis, mongoDB, react, cluster) at you all at once and it's harder to figure out exactly what is doing what.
Project 3 is interesting but I'm not sure how I would run it in a real life basis.
Project 3 needs a final walkthrough of what everything is doing.  It feels like it just dropped off.
results.content_html:
Pros:
Projects are easy to follow
Project 1 and 2 are easy and I feel I learned a lot about sockets

Cons:
Projects are more a walk through and I find myself doing more copying than coding
Uses React Class Components in project 3 which is a little outdated

Project 3 throws a lot of new technologies (redis, mongoDB, react, cluster) at you all at once and it's harder to figure out exactly what is doing what.
Project 3 is interesting but I'm not sure how I would run it in a real life basis.
Project 3 needs a final walkthrough of what everything is doing. It feels like it just dropped off.

I'm looking forward to the next projects, especially the video streaming one.

results.content: I'm really enjoying this course. The lecturer follows a very clear logic of showing everything in order. Also, I find the projects very practical and well-explained. I am a starter in socket.io and I find the content very interesting. I never feel bored! Thank you lecturer for conducting such a solid course!

results.content: Great course, learned a lot. What can be improved? The game project has some little bugs. You start with only some starter files and during the course you build these into a game (great!). But if you make a mistake there are no intermediate files. So it is not possible to compare your own files with these intermediate files. I had to spend a lot of time to search for the mistake I made. But hey that's how you learn. :)

results.content:
I wish there wasn't so much copy pasting of code. It ruins the whole experience. I prefer typing everything from scratch but the instructor is too lazy to.

I would also prefer if there was better architecture of code as it seemed too abstract, something that won't be used in production. Seems like bad coding practices were taught.

//Edit
I finished the course and I really liked the performance monitor project. I learnt how to use clusters which is in fact an amazing tool to use with socket.io! I loved the concept and the project however, I wish I knew more about redis and node.js to full understand the project. I am now trying to deploy the app to Heroku hopefully succeeding so that I can show others the cool thing I made in this course.

results.content:
Great explanation of the topics and concepts at hand.  I really appreciated the in-depth explanation of just what was happening in the programs as we progressed.

One small recommendation: when we are following along and typing our own code and you complete a line, pause just a second before moving on to the next thought (especially when changing between tabs on a screen).  I can't tell you how many times I had to pause, rewind 5 seconds, and restart to make sure I caught the right text.  Minor thing that really adds up over a long course.
results.content_html:
